keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a New York man convicted of participating in the January 6, 2021, Capitol attack, was arrested on a charge of threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct in a restricted area during the Capitol attack.

President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier in 2025, along with other January 6 defendants, sparking criticism from Hakeem Jeffries, who condemned the 'blanket pardon' as enabling threats of violence.
Moynihan allegedly threatened to kill Jeffries in a text message stating: 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.'
New York State Police reported that Moynihan showed signs of recent drug abuse and increased homicidal ideations, raising concerns about public safety and mental health.
Moynihan's attorneys previously noted his struggle with opiate addiction and claimed his political engagement increased during the Trump administration.
A New York judge ordered Moynihan to remain in prison while awaiting a hearing on release pending trial, citing no representation from attorneys and a lack of legal counsel.
The incident occurs amid heightened national concern over political violence, following the recent assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man convicted of participating in the January 6, 2021, Capitol attack, Christopher Moynihan, was arrested in October 2025 on a charge of threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan had previously been sentenced to nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct. Despite being pardoned by former President Donald Trump earlier in 2025, Moynihan was arrested after allegedly sending threatening texts stating he would kill Jeffries for political reasons. Authorities reported signs of drug abuse and increased homicidal ideations, and Moynihan remains in prison pending a hearing on release. The incident reflects broader national concerns about political violence, especially in the wake of the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk, and raises questions about the impact of executive pardons on public safety.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
